In the past, there were five kings whose kingdoms were neighboring each other, they went to each other's countries and did not attack each other,
only making good friends.
The eldest one was named King Pu'an, who practiced the bodhisattva path;
the other four small kings always practiced evil ways.
The great king had pity on them and wanted to save them, so he called them to the palace, entertained them together, for seven days, all day and night, with singing and music.
After seven days, the four kings said to the great king:
There are many state affairs, please return to govern.
The great king said to the attendants:
Prepare the carriages, all the ministers and people will see them off together.
Halfway there, the great king had pity on them and wanted to save them, so he said to the four kings:
Each of you speak about what you enjoy.
One king said:
I wish to have the three months of spring, with the trees in full bloom. Playing and roaming in the fields is what I enjoy.
Another king said:

I wish to always be a king, with horses and carriages, towers and halls, officials and people surrounding me to the left and right, shining brightly, beating drums and ringing bells, coming and going, with passersby staring in awe. This is what I enjoy.
Another king said:
What I enjoy is different.
I wish to have a beautiful wife and handsome children, unparalleled in appearance, enjoying each other's company and indulging in pleasures to the fullest. This is what I enjoy.
Another king said:
What I enjoy is different.

I wish for my parents to always be present, with many brothers, wives, and children. Wearing fine clothes and eating delicious food to satisfy my appetite, playing the zither and wearing light clothing to enjoy each other's company. This is what I enjoy.
Each having finished speaking of what they enjoyed, the Four Heavenly Kings all turned their heads and said to the Great King:
What do you enjoy, Your Majesty?
The Great King replied:
I will first speak of what you enjoy, and then speak of my own enjoyment.

One of you said, 'In the three months of early spring, the trees are in full bloom, and I enjoy playing in the fields.' But in autumn they wither and fall, and this is not lasting enjoyment.ğŸ”½You said, 'I wish to always be a king, with saddles and horses, towers and halls, officials and people surrounding me to the left and right, shining brightly, beating bells and drums, coming and going, with passersby staring. The kings of the past, with their hidden and crowded splendor, had ultimate happiness, but their blessings and virtues were exhausted, and the countries fought each other. Suddenly they collapsed and perished, and this is not lasting enjoyment.'
You said, 'I wish to be a wealthy and noble person, with a large house, many servants, and abundant food and drink. I will enjoy myself for a while, and when I am tired of it, I will become a monk.'

You said, 'I wish to have a good wife and good children, handsome and unparalleled, to enjoy each other's company and indulge in pleasures to our heart's content.' But in one morning, if you fall ill, the suffering will be immeasurable, and it will not last long.

You said, 'I wish my parents are always alive, have many brothers and wives, and have fine clothes and delicious food to satisfy my mouth, play the zither and wear light clothes to enjoy each other's company.' But in one morning, if something happens and you are arrested by the officials, imprisoned, with no one to rescue you, this is not lasting happiness.
The four people asked together:
What do you, the king, enjoy?
The king said:
I enjoy not being born or dying, not suffering or being troubled, not being hungry or thirsty, not being cold or hot, and being free to live or die. This is my happiness.
The four kings all said:
Where is this happiness?
Will there be a wise teacher?
The great king replied:
My teacher is called the Buddha, and he is currently staying at the Jetavana Monastery.
The kings joyfully went to where the Buddha was, bowed their heads in reverence, and sat to one side.
The great king knelt with his hands clasped and said to the Buddha:
We have now become humans, but we are dull, ignorant, and lack wisdom. We are deeply attached to worldly pleasures and do not know what is right or wrong.
We hope that the Buddha will explain the truth of suffering for us disciples.
The Buddha said:
You should listen well!
I will explain it for you.
When a person is born in the world, they are constantly afflicted by immeasurable suffering. Now I will briefly explain the eight kinds of suffering for you.
What are the eight kinds of suffering?

The suffering of birth, the suffering of old age, the suffering of sickness, the suffering of death, the suffering of separation from loved ones, the suffering of not obtaining what one desires, the suffering of encountering what one hates, and the suffering of worry, sorrow, and distress.
These are the eight kinds of suffering.
What is meant by the suffering of birth?

When a person dies, they do not know where their spirit will go. Before obtaining a place to be reborn, they all receive a form in the intermediate state, and after twenty-one days, if their parents unite, they will come to receive a womb.ğŸ”½After one seven-day period, it is like thin yogurt;
after two seven-day periods, it is like thick yogurt;
after three seven-day periods, it is like coagulated butter;
after four seven-day periods, it is like a piece of meat. After five sheaths are formed, a skillful wind enters the abdomen and blows on the body, opening up the six sense faculties.
In the mother's womb, it is below the liver and above the intestines. If the mother drinks a cup of hot food, it pours over the body, like entering a hot spring;
if the mother drinks a cup of cold water, it is also like cold ice cutting the body;
when the mother is full, the body is squeezed and the pain is indescribable;
when the mother is hungry, the stomach rumbles, and it is also like being hung upside down, suffering countless hardships.
When the time comes for the mother to give birth, the baby's head faces the birth canal, as if being squeezed between two rocks;
When the time comes for the baby to be born, the mother is in danger and the father is terrified.
After birth, the baby is laid on the grass, the body delicate and soft, the grass touching the body like walking on swords and knives, suddenly losing its voice and crying out loud.
Is this not suffering?
The people all said:
This is great suffering.
What is the suffering of old age?

Parents raise and nurture until adulthood, thinking themselves strong and healthy, carrying light and heavy loads, not knowing moderation, freezing in extreme cold, sweating in extreme heat, starving in extreme hunger, and overeating when full, without restraint;

Gradually reaching old age, with white hair and falling teeth, eyes that see dimly, and ears that do not hear clearly, the flourishing gone and decline arrived, skin loose and face wrinkled, a hundred joints aching, walking and standing suffering to the extreme, sitting and rising moaning, a mind troubled by sorrow and grief, the consciousness turning and extinguishing, revolving and immediately forgetting, life's days quickly ending, speaking with tears flowing, sitting and rising needing others' help.
Is this suffering or not?
The great king replied:
Indeed, it is great suffering.
What is meant by the suffering of illness?
A person has the four great elements, which combine to form their body - what are the four great elements?

The earth element, water element, fire element, and wind element - when one great element is unbalanced, a hundred and one illnesses arise, when the four great elements are unbalanced, the four hundred and four illnesses occur simultaneously.
When the earth element is unbalanced, the whole body becomes heavy;ğŸ”½when the water element is unbalanced, the whole body becomes swollen;
when the fire element is unbalanced, the whole body becomes steamed and hot;
When the wind element is out of balance, the whole body becomes stiff, and the pain in the hundred joints is as if being beaten with a stick.

The four elements advance and retreat, the hands and feet are unable to function, the vital energy is exhausted, sitting up and lying down require the help of others, the mouth is dry and the lips are parched, the muscles break and the nose cracks, the eyes cannot see colors, the ears cannot hear sounds, impurities flow out, the body lies on top of them, the mind is full of suffering, the words are full of sadness, the six relatives are by the side, watching day and night without rest, and the delicious food that enters the mouth is all bitter.
Is this suffering or not?
He replied:
It is indeed great suffering.
What is the suffering of death?
When a person is dying, the four hundred and four diseases all occur at the same time, the four elements are about to disperse, and the soul and spirit are uneasy.
When about to die, the knife-wind severs the body, there is no place that is not painful, white sweat flows out, and the two hands grope in the air.
The family members, both inside and outside, to his left and right, grieved and wept, the pain penetrating to the bone marrow, unable to bear it.
When a person dies, the wind leaves, the breath ceases, the fire goes out, and the body becomes cold. The wind leaves first, then the fire.
The soul and spirit depart, and the body becomes straight, knowing nothing more.

Within ten days, the flesh decays, blood flows, it swells and rots, the stench is indescribable, and it is discarded in the wilderness, where the birds eat it. The flesh is exhausted, the bones dry up, and the skull is in a different place.
Is this suffering?
He replied:
Indeed, it is great suffering.
What is the suffering of separation from loved ones?

The whole family, inside and out, brothers and wives, love and miss each other, but in one morning they are ruined, robbed by others, each scattered, the father east, the son west, the mother south, the daughter north, not in only one place, becoming slaves for others, each crying in their hearts, cut off, dark and gloomy, without a chance to see each other.
Is this suffering or not?
He replied:
Indeed, it is great suffering.
What is the suffering of not obtaining what is sought?

The family has money and property, but spends it pursuing high officials, hoping to become rich and noble. They toil and struggle to seek it, seeking it without stopping, and happen to obtain it, becoming a border magistrate.

Before long, they greedily take the people's goods, and people report them. In one morning, when something happens, they are put in a cage and taken away. When they are about to be executed, their worries and suffering are immeasurable, not knowing when they will die or live.
Is this suffering or not?
He said:ğŸ”½Yes, it is suffering.
It is indeed great suffering.
What is the suffering of being with what is disliked?

Worldly people are shallow and vulgar, living together in desire, quarreling over unimportant matters, killing each other, eventually becoming great enemies, each trying to avoid the other, with nowhere to hide, sharpening their knives and arrows, carrying bows and sticks, fearing to meet each other, encountering each other on a narrow path, each drawing their bows and arrows, two swords facing each other, not knowing who will win or lose, at that moment, the fear is immeasurable.
Is this suffering?
He replied:
It is indeed great suffering.
What is the suffering of worry, sorrow, and distress?
People born in the world, those with long lives up to a hundred years, and those with short lives miscarrying in the womb.
For those with long lives, out of their hundred years, half is spent in sleep, leaving fifty years;
In drunkenness and illness, not knowing how to act, five years are subtracted;
foolish for a short time;
for fifteen years, not yet knowing propriety;
over eighty years old, old and dull, without wisdom, deaf and blind, without rules, and lacking twenty years;
already ninety years, with only ten years left, full of worries -
when the world is about to become chaotic, I worry; when there is a drought in the world, I worry; when there is a great flood in the world, I worry;
when there is heavy frost in the world, I worry; when the crops are not ripe in the world, I worry; when there are many illnesses in the household, inside and out, I worry;

when holding the family wealth and fearing loss in business, I worry; when the hundred taxes of the government have not been paid, I worry; when the family encounters official matters, is imprisoned in jail, and the date of release is unknown, I worry;

when brothers, wife, and children are traveling far and have not returned, I worry; when the household is poor and cold, without clothing or food, I worry; when there are matters in the neighboring village, I worry; when the community offerings are not prepared,
also sad, with the death of family members and no wealth for burial, also sad, by the time of spring

They also worry when family members die and have no property for burial. They also worry when it's spring and time to plant but have no oxen to plow. Such various sorrows and laments are always without joy.
When it comes to their festival days, they gather together and should be joyful, but they only weep and face each other.
Is this not suffering?
They replied:
Indeed, it is great suffering.

At that time, the five kings and the many millions of people in the assembly, upon hearing the explanation of the truth of suffering, their minds opened up and they attained the path of stream-entry. They were all greatly delighted, paid homage, and left.
The four kings all said to King Universal Peace:
Great King, you are truly a great skillful means bodhisattva who has transformed us and enabled us to attain the path of stream-entry. It is the great king's grace.
I originally observed the palaces, my mind attached to them, unable to be far away. Now, seeing the palaces is like looking at a filthy latrine, with nothing lovable.
